def.title: Definition of hypothesis testing
def.p1: Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a family of probability distributions, and let $\mathcal{F}_0$ and $\mathcal{F}_1$ be two disjoint subsets of $\mathcal{F}$.
def.p2: Let $F^{(n)}$ be the distribution of the sample $X = (X_1, \ldots, X_n)$.
def.p3: A test is a decision procedure to determine whether $F^{(n)}$ belongs to $H_0$ or $H_1$.
param.title: Parametric model
param.p1: Sometimes we assume a parametric family $\mathcal{P} = \{ P_\theta,\, \theta \in \Theta \}$. In that case, hypothesis testing can be formulated in terms of parameters rather than distributions.
param.p2: The null hypothesis specifies $\theta \in \Theta_0$ (a subset of $\Theta$), while the alternative specifies $\theta \in \Theta_1$, with $\Theta_0 \cap \Theta_1 = \emptyset$.
param.p3: Based on the observed data $X$, we decide whether to accept $H$ (that $\theta \in \Theta_0$) or to reject $H$ and accept $K$ (that $\theta \in \Theta_1$).
simple.title: Simple hypothesis
simple.p1: If $\Theta_0$ consists of only one point, the hypothesis $H$ is called simple.
simple.p2: If $\Theta_0$ contains more than one point, then $H$ is called composite.
